title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
The analysis of name usage trends revealed fascinating insights into the popularity of selected names over the years. Examining the historical data for names such as Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul from 1920 to 2000 showcased distinct patterns. While Mary maintained consistent popularity, Martha experienced a decline, and Peter and Paul exhibited fluctuations. Additionally, a closer look at the name ‘Vito’ aligned with the release of the movie “The Godfather” in 1972, indicating a notable surge in popularity around that time. 


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4names/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
The analysis of name usage trends revealed fascinating insights into the popularity of selected names over the years. Examining the historical data for names such as Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul from 1920 to 2000 showcased distinct patterns. While Mary maintained consistent popularity, Martha experienced a decline, and Peter and Paul exhibited fluctuations. Additionally, a closer look at the name ‘Vito’ aligned with the release of the movie “The Godfather” in 1972, indicating a notable surge in popularity around that time. 


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4names/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
QUESTION|TASK 1
How does your name at your birth year compare to its use historically?
My name is Aayush. Because the name is well-known in other parts of the world, it sticks out. The data indicates that it hasn’t been used all that much. When I was born in 2004, there were 39 babies with the name Aayush. Although historically very few people have used the name Aayush, its use peaked in 2010 with 49 people using it. My name was not very common before 2001.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
# pd.unique(df.query('name == "Aayush"').year).size
aayush_data = df[df['name'] == 'Aayush']

# Plot the historical usage of the name
fig = px.line(aayush_data, x='year', y='Total', title='Historical Usage of the Name Aayush')

# Add a vertical line for your birth year
your_birth_year = 2004  
fig.add_shape(
    dict(
        type='line',
        x0=your_birth_year,
        x1=your_birth_year,
        y0=0,
        y1=aayush_data['Total'].max(),
        line=dict(color='red', dash='dash'),
        name='Your Birth Year'
    )
)

fig.add_annotation(
    x=your_birth_year,
    y=aayush_data['Total'].max(),
    text='Birth Year \'2004\'',
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=2,
    arrowcolor='red',
    ax=0,
    ay=-40
)

fig.show()

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
QUESTION|TASK 2
If you talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, what is your guess of his or her age? What ages would you not guess?
If I talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, my guess of his or her age would be around 34 or 33. The graph indicates that in 1990, this name peaked at around 32k. The individual I spoke with may therefore be in their 30s. After 1990, this name gradually became less common. In a comparable way, I wouldn’t guess that someone with this name is older than 50 because, based on the provided graphs, no one had this name in 1970.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
brittany_data = df[df['name'] == 'Brittany']
fig = px.bar(brittany_data, x='year', y='Total', title='Age Distribution for Brittany')
fig.show()

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
QUESTION|TASK 3
Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul are all Christian names. From 1920 - 2000, compare the name usage of each of the four names. What trends do you notice?
Comparing the popularity of these four Christian names, we can conclude that Mary was the most popular. A peak of 53k was reached by this name in 1950. Out of these four names, Paul is the second most popular and was very well-known from 1950 to 1970. Paul reached about 25k in 1954. Compared to the other two names, Peter and Martha were not in the trends. But in 1956, there were about 10,000 people with the name Peter. In addition, Martha was named roughly 10,000 in 1947. In summary, after the 1950s, the names mentioned above saw a decline in popularity, and by 2000, they had fallen out of popularity.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
names_list = ['Mary', 'Martha', 'Peter', 'Paul']
selected_names_data = df[df['name'].isin(names_list)]
selected_names_data = selected_names_data[(selected_names_data['year'] >= 1920) & (selected_names_data['year'] <= 2000)]
fig = px.line(selected_names_data, x='year', y='Total', color='name', title='Name Usage Comparison (1920 - 2000)')
fig.show()

title: Unveiling Historical Name Trends
text:
QUESTION|TASK 4
Think of a unique name from a famous movie. Plot the usage of that name and see how changes line up with the movie release. Does it look like the movie had an effect on usage?
One of the characters in the 1972 film “The Godfather” was called Vito. There were 300 persons named Vito in 1925. But by 1940, things had drastically changed, and the data had reached 95. In 1972, this name was only used by 95. Vito’s name began to progressively fade after the film’s release.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
movie_release_year = 1972
unique_name = 'Vito'

vito_data = df[df['name'] == unique_name]

fig = px.line(vito_data, x='year', y='Total', title=f'Name Usage Over Time for {unique_name}')
fig.update_layout(
    shapes=[
        dict(
            type='line',
            x0=movie_release_year,
            x1=movie_release_year,
            y0=0,
            y1=vito_data['Total'].max(),
            line=dict(color='red', dash='dash'),
            name='Movie Release Year'
        )
    ]
)

fig.add_annotation(
    x=movie_release_year,
    y=vito_data['Total'].max(),
    text='Movie Release year \'1972\'',
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=2,
    arrowcolor='red',
    ax=0,
    ay=-40
)
fig.show()

Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - Project 02
text:
paste your elevator pitch here A SHORT (4-5 SENTENCES) PARAGRAPH THAT DESCRIBES KEY INSIGHTS TAKEN FROM METRICS IN THE PROJECT RESULTS THINK TOP OR MOST IMPORTANT RESULTS.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_json("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4missing/master/data-raw/flights_missing/flights_missing.json")


Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - Project 02
text:
QUESTION|TASK 1
Fix all of the varied missing data types in the data to be consistent (all missing values should be displayed as “NaN”). In your report include one record example (one row) from your new data, in the raw JSON format. Your example should display the “NaN” for at least one missing value.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
df.replace([None, 'NA', 'N/A', 'na', 'n/a', 'nan', 'None', 'none'], 'NaN', inplace=True)

one_record_example = df.iloc[921].to_dict()
print("One Record Example (Raw JSON Format):")
print(one_record_example)


One Record Example (Raw JSON Format):
{'airport_code': 'SAN', 'airport_name': 'San Diego, CA: San Diego International', 'month': 'NaN', 'year': 2015.0, 'num_of_flights_total': 6231, 'num_of_delays_carrier': '480', 'num_of_delays_late_aircraft': 606, 'num_of_delays_nas': 256, 'num_of_delays_security': 5, 'num_of_delays_weather': 37, 'num_of_delays_total': 1383, 'minutes_delayed_carrier': 25402.0, 'minutes_delayed_late_aircraft': 35796, 'minutes_delayed_nas': 9038.0, 'minutes_delayed_security': 161, 'minutes_delayed_weather': 2742, 'minutes_delayed_total': 73139}

title: Client Report - Project 02
text:
QUESTION|TASK 2
Which airport has the worst delays? Discuss the metric you chose, and why you chose it to determine the “worst” airport. Your answer should include a summary table that lists (for each airport) the total number of flights, total number of delayed flights, proportion of delayed flights, and average delay time in hours.
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here

df['month'].unique()

# Group by airport_code and aggregate relevant columns
grouped_data = df.groupby('airport_code')[['num_of_flights_total', 'num_of_delays_total', 'minutes_delayed_total']].agg('sum')

# Create a new DataFrame with calculated metrics
result = (grouped_data
          .assign(
              proportion_delayed=lambda row: row['num_of_delays_total'] / row['num_of_flights_total'],
              average_delay_time_hours=lambda row: row['minutes_delayed_total'] / (60 * row['num_of_flights_total'])
          )
          .sort_values('num_of_flights_total', ascending=False)
)

result['proportion_delayed'] = result['proportion_delayed'].apply(lambda x: '{:.2%}'.format(x))
result['average_delay_time_hours'] = result['average_delay_time_hours'].apply(lambda x: '{:.2f} hrs'.format(x))

# Create a summary table using Plotly Express table
print(result)

title: Client Report - Project 02
text:
QUESTION|TASK 3
What is the best month to fly if you want to avoid delays of any length? Discuss the metric you chose and why you chose it to calculate your answer. Include one chart to help support your answer, with the x-axis ordered by month. (To answer this question, you will need to remove any rows that are missing the Month variable.)
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
import plotly.figure_factory as ff
df = df.dropna(subset=['month'])

# Correct the spelling of Febuary to February for all records in the months
df['month'] = df['month'].replace('Febuary', 'February')

# Calculate the total number of flights and delays per month
monthly_stats = df.groupby('month')[['num_of_flights_total', 'num_of_delays_total']].sum().reset_index()

# Calculate the proportion of delayed flights for each month
monthly_stats['proportion_delayed'] = monthly_stats['num_of_delays_total'] / monthly_stats['num_of_flights_total']

# Create a bar chart using Plotly Express
fig = px.bar(monthly_stats, x='month', y='proportion_delayed', 
             title='Proportion of Delayed Flights by Month',
             labels={'proportion_delayed': 'Proportion Delayed'},
             category_orders={'month': ['January', 'February', 'March', 'April', 'May', 'June', 'July', 'August', 'September', 'October', 'November', 'December']})

# Show the plot
fig.show()


                                                


include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.

title: Client Report - Project 02
text:
QUESTION|TASK 4
According to the BTS website, the “Weather” category only accounts for severe weather delays. Mild weather delays are not counted in the “Weather” category, but are actually included in both the “NAS” and “Late-Arriving Aircraft” categories. Your job is to create a new column that calculates the total number of flights delayed by weather (both severe and mild). You will need to replace all the missing values in the Late Aircraft variable with the mean. Show your work by printing the first 5 rows of data in a table. Use these three rules for your calculations:
100% of delayed flights in the Weather category are due to weather
30% of all delayed flights in the Late-Arriving category are due to weather.
From April to August, 40% of delayed flights in the NAS category are due to weather. The rest of the months, the proportion rises to 65%.
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here

# Calculate the mean of 'Late Aircraft' excluding missing values
mean_delay_late_aircraft = df[df['num_of_delays_late_aircraft'] != 'NaN']['num_of_delays_late_aircraft'].mean()

# Replace missing values with the mean
df['num_of_delays_late_aircraft'] = df['num_of_delays_late_aircraft'].replace('NaN', mean_delay_late_aircraft)

df['severe'] = df['num_of_delays_weather']
df['mild_late'] = df['num_of_delays_late_aircraft'] * 0.3
df['mild_nas'] = np.where(df['month'].isin(['April', 'May', 'June', 'July', 'August']),
                          df['num_of_delays_nas'] * 0.4,
                          df['num_of_delays_nas'] * 0.65)
df['weather_total'] = df['severe'] + df['mild_late'] + df['mild_nas']

# Check and convert data types before rounding
numeric_columns = ['severe', 'mild_late', 'mild_nas', 'weather_total']
df[numeric_columns] = df[numeric_columns].apply(pd.to_numeric, errors='coerce')

# Format and rounding only numeric columns
df[numeric_columns] = df[numeric_columns].apply(lambda x: round(x,2))

# Display the first 5 rows of the DataFrame with selected columns
print(df[numeric_columns].head())

title: Client Report - Project 02
text:
QUESTION|TASK 5
Using the new weather variable calculated above, create a barplot showing the proportion of all flights that are delayed by weather at each airport. Discuss what you learn from this graph.
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
df['proportion_delayed_weather'] = df['minutes_delayed_weather'] / df['minutes_delayed_total']

# Create a bar chart using Plotly Express
fig = px.bar(df, x='airport_code', y='proportion_delayed_weather', 
             title='Proportion of Flights Delayed by Weather at Each Airport',
             labels={'proportion_delayed_weather': 'Proportion Delayed by Weather'})

# Show the plot
fig.show()
